text:
Thank you <@U0353AN9487>, I like the clarity of the process you mentioned... map the questions each persona has along the journey, then see what content we have to answer those questions.
Rework/re-write content to better tackle the questions and/or create new content as required.
I'm curious to know what tools you use for this process, or is it mostly done in spreadsheets/templates?

I'm personally a fan of the Storybrand book so please to see you mention this. I found a great PDF after a bit of searching today which is useful, but mostly focusses on the core message on websites rather than a content strategy.
Will give the Content Strategy course a try - on first glance it looks good though :+1:

Appreciated :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Thanks <@UUH2EB134>, this makes logical sense to me.

It sounds a lot like a Value Proposition Canvas but with content mapped to it.

I can see that visualising the customer journey by effectively giving the value prop canvas a timeline would be really useful for both understanding what content we have, and spotting the gaps where we don't have any content on certain problems.

Is this what you have in mind?
Any tools or templates you know of that does this well?

text: Hey folks.. So I head the content division at a SaaS startup.. and we make chatbots. Now, the product is not too complicated, which means the competition is cut-throat in this field. How do I differentiate our company so that we tell a story our competitors may have missed? Any articles / guides / resources you can point me towards? Or general advice is also good.

elements.text: Hey folks.. So I head the content division at a SaaS startup.. and we make chatbots. Now, the product is not too complicated, which means the competition is cut-throat in this field. How do I differentiate our company so that we tell a story our competitors may have missed? Any articles / guides / resources you can point me towards? Or general advice is also good.

text:
Research your competitors’ marketing. Find out what they’re saying, then find a way to say it differently — or, better yet, say something else entirely.

Also, this shouldn’t fall squarely on your shoulders. How is the product team building a differentiated product? How does sales position your differentiation on calls?

elements.text:

Also, this shouldn’t fall squarely on your shoulders. How is the product team building a differentiated product? How does sales position your differentiation on calls?

text: Hey <@U024SFM3YK0>, a couple of years ago we did a lot of customer journey research at Hotjar + interviewed some experts and turned it all into a pretty comprehensive guide if you'd like to check it out. I don't know that it covers everything you want, but there are definitely real-life examples and visualisations in there :slightly_smiling_face: → <https://web.archive.org/web/20201125061423/https://www.hotjar.com/customer-journey-map/>

attachments.fallback: Hotjar: How to Create a Customer Journey Map: Template & Guide
attachments.text: A customer journey map is a visual overview of how customers experience your business across multiple touchpoints. Here’s how to get started.
attachments.title: How to Create a Customer Journey Map: Template & Guide

text: Thanks <@U02ME70EHBL> for the kind advice. The Sales team at this point is just one person, and the way we are selling it is by taking the angle of "how easy it is to build a chatbot".. which is our USP. Most of our leads come through organic channels. But these have been drying up of late, partially because we have competitors who have 5X our budget pushing out better blog posts / more content out there and putting that in front of our clients through paid ads. Is there anything I can do to beat them?

elements.text: Thanks

for the kind advice. The Sales team at this point is just one person, and the way we are selling it is by taking the angle of "how easy it is to build a chatbot".. which is our USP. Most of our leads come through organic channels. But these have been drying up of late, partially because we have competitors who have 5X our budget pushing out better blog posts / more content out there and putting that in front of our clients through paid ads. Is there anything I can do to beat them?

text: I think this is less a problem for content strategy to solve and more one for brand positioning to solve (brand positioning will, of course, inform your content strategy). I would recommend working through some simple positioning exercises to land on your unique PoV compared to others and then lean into that key message across all comms, internal and external. Ease-of-use, unfortunately, is pretty table stakes in SaaS today (as are any claims of saving time & money) so try to stand for something more magnetic and less likely to be the same claims as your competitors. Bring that to life through your visual identity, voice & tone marketing activities, and even things like CSR etc.

Bring that to life through your visual identity, voice & tone marketing activities, and even things like CSR etc.

text: I literally do conversational marketing for clients and the biggest thing I can tell you is how reliable they are and the visual builder. If you make it AWFUL (like intercom and hubspot), people are less likely to adopt it. Using a builder like Drift or Voiceflow is a MUST.

elements.text: I literally do conversational marketing for clients and the biggest thing I can tell you is how reliable they are and the visual builder. If you make it AWFUL (like intercom and hubspot), people are less likely to adopt it. Using a builder like Drift or Voiceflow is a MUST.

text: IMO, teach people how to actually build bots that do stuff. Drift is awful at this and the market is WIDE open.

text: How do you go about doing a technical SEO audit for a large website?

elements.text: How do you go about doing a technical SEO audit for a large website?

text: You need some level of technical/development help. Running ScreamingFrog (or similar) is usually the first step. Most tools will show technical misconfiguration issues.

elements.text: You need some level of technical/development help. Running ScreamingFrog (or similar) is usually the first step. Most tools will show technical misconfiguration issues.

text: There's a pretty good guide here from Moz: <https://moz.com/blog/how-to-perform-the-worlds-greatest-seo-audit> -- but yes, it'll likely start with a tool like Screaming Frog. You'll need a paid version if the site is larger than 500 pages, the cost is pretty affordable. The article is older but there's a good process to follow. You'll need to add things like checking how they score on Core Web Vitals to performance aspects now though. This is a deeper look at technical SEO items and much more recent too: <https://backlinko.com/technical-seo-guide>

elements.text: There's a pretty good guide here from Moz:

elements.text:
I'm working for a B2B client ramping up its thought leadership from its 4 co-founders. Our writers are fantastic, but so far their ghostwriting work has missed the mark in representing a founder's voice and story in an authentic way.

My question to you:
How have you onboarded a writer to someone's voice and perspective they'll be ghostwriting for?
I'm thinking of hosting a training session, to start. The founders will share their stories, we can discuss how to speak to certain details, etc.

text: For messaging strategy, I like to use Storybrand, so I'd recommend looking up their framework and building one out for your brand. However, one thing it misses is the three uniques. Find three things that set your brand apart. They don't all have to be 100% unique to your brand, but combined, there's NO ONE else that does all three. Find yours :slightly_smiling_face: I'd say this is even more important than StoryBrand.

elements.text: For messaging strategy, I like to use Storybrand, so I'd recommend looking up their framework and building one out for your brand. However, one thing it misses is the three uniques. Find three things that set your brand apart. They don't all have to be 100% unique to your brand, but combined, there's NO ONE else that does all three. Find yours
I'd say this is even more important than StoryBrand.

text:
Hey Ya’ll! I have a question for the group. I am looking to find an agency or a source that can help build out those super comprehensive data-backed content pieces (i.e., the State of Email Compliance in 2022). Is there one you would recommend that could do something like that? I am thinking one that also involves surveys  professionals (in our case compliance and legal professionals) and helps to put together these reports)?

I see Wistia, Drift, Buffer, and Gong create a lot of content like this - and overtime generates tons of backlinks, and credibility.
